column4: so I just did "mv log /linode" where log was a text file and linode was a folder in the same directory.  log has disappeared and doesn't show up on a file system search.  What just happened?
so it's all the way in my root directory?  Not the directory where I ran the command?
Because you gave it /linode (meaning a folder named linode in /) not just linode (meaning a folder in this folder)
ahh I found it.  But it's not a folder - log is still a file but now it's named linode
If there was no folder /linode (a folder named linode in /) then the command would have created a file named linode in root (that is actually log)
so now it's not letting me delete the file from my gui
The gui is not root so it cannot edit things in /
I presume you actually run sudo mv log /linode
so I have to use absolute paths when using the mv command?  Are there any shortcuts for this?
That made you root when you did it so the new file /linode which is actually a moved and renamed log is owned by root.  You need to be root to edit it
You do not have to use absolute paths.  You did just now.  Any path starting with / is absolute (it's starts from /   !!)
What you wanted to run was probably mv log linode/   (a trailing slash indicates a folder) but if it already is a folder the system figures it out.
so that would work in my current directory?  It would automatically find the folder linode?
If there is a folder in your current working directory it would find it.  (yes)
